natural problem:
Compute the sum and enter your answer as a common fraction:
$$
\begin{array}{r r@{}c@{}l}
& 1 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 01111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00011111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00001111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00000111\ldots \\
+ &&\vdots \\
\hline
&&& ~~~?
\end{array}
$$
natural solution: The first addend, $1.11111111\ldots$, is by itself equal to the sum of the infinite geometric series $$1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^3+\cdots,$$which is $\frac 1{1-\frac 1{10}}=\frac{10}9$.
The second addend is one-tenth of this, so equals $\frac 19$. The third addend is one-tenth of the second addend, and so on.

Thus the sum of the infinite column of infinite decimals is \begin{align} \frac{10}9\cdot\left[1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\cdots\right] &= \frac{10}9\cdot\frac{10}9 \\ &= \boxed{\frac{100}{81}}.
\end{align}Notice that we have just added $1+\frac 2{10}+\frac 3{100}+\frac 4{1000}+\cdots$, sneakily.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. S n = (1/10) ^ n"
shows  "sum S {1..n} = 100/81"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the sum and enter your answer as a common fraction:
$$
\begin{array}{r r@{}c@{}l}
& 1 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 01111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00011111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00001111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00000111\ldots \\
+ &&\vdots \\
\hline
&&& ~~~?
\end{array}
$$ The final Answer is \frac{100}{81}
 ### Proof
 The first addend, $1.11111111\ldots$, is by itself equal to the sum of the infinite geometric series $$1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^3+\cdots,$$which is $\frac 1{1-\frac 1{10}}=\frac{10}9$.
 The second addend is one-tenth of this, so equals $\frac 19$. The third addend is one-tenth of the second addend, and so on.
 Thus the sum of the infinite column of infinite decimals is \begin{align} \frac{10}9\cdot\left[1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\cdots\right] &= \frac{10}9\cdot\frac{10}9 \\ &= \boxed{\frac{100}{81}}.
 \end{align}Notice that we have just added $1+\frac 2{10}+\frac 3{100}+\frac 4{1000}+\cdots$, sneakily.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and S :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. S n = (1/10) ^ n"
shows  "sum S {1..n} = 100/81"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of the series where the nth term is given by $(1/10)^n$ for all natural numbers $n$. The final answer is $\frac{100}{81}$.
